user.biography:
🥃 Whiskey enthusiast.
🇺🇸 Proud retired Spec Ops Army Veteran.  Hondu ‘84, Berlin ‘88, Mogadishu ‘93
🙏 Honored to have walked among so many giants!

node.text: Testing my new #ballisticplates and new #prosthesis while honoring my longtime friend and teammate. #moh

node.title: Run to Remember MSG Gary Gordon, Medal of Honor recipient and mate.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Brad Halling in Mogadishu, Banadir, Somalia.

node.text:
Black Hawk Down: Thoughts from my memoirs:  14 Sep 1993 (part 1)

Sitting on my cot in the hot humid hangar, I reflected on the most current event! Last night Aidid’s men attempted to hit American forces by launching a 120 mm mortar. Thankfully they lack any kind of fires training and therefore accuracy. Still, nonetheless, law of probability tells me if they get enough off, eventually one will hit its mark!

Happy to be a part of this amazing fighting force, wanting the mission, but hoping we could quickly do our work, capture Aidid, and go home. My thoughts were “ there is nothing here worth an American life”. As I reflect on all the flights over the city I am still unsure what the clans are even fighting for?

The call came … we have intell suggesting a possible sighting. Quickly, I grabbed my pistol belt, strapped on my kit, and grabbed my rifle hanging on the old plastered wall of the hangar room and headed to Super 62. With its blades already churning and the rotor blast cutting the air, I jumped in hoping this was the one.

The target, the Jilao house. As we approach the target some of the red tin roofs started separating from the deteriorating dwellings they were resting on, always a concern to a Blackhawk or any rotory wing for that matter.

The pilots of the 160th SOAR skillfully made there way to target dodging the flying debris. Quickly, they put the aircraft into a flare and the fast ropes went out!

This target was different from the others. Looking out I could already see crowds forming. This would be the first target in which we would use non- lethal means to control the mob …. We would use stun grenades (pictured in photo) filled with rubber pellets and simply toss them into the crowds from our sniper platform, the helicopter!
 
to be continued….

 @hallingwhiskey #blackhawkdown #blackhawk #gothicserpent #1911 #car15 #sniper #sniperrifles #moh #purpleheart #taskforceranger #specialoperations #jsoc #usasoc #sealteamsix #pow #fortbragg #fortbraggnc #southernpines #160thsoar #rltw #dol #moorecounty #southernpinesnc #southernpines #fayettevillenc #sinepari #aberdeennc #sanfordnc #againstallodds #oakley #worldstopwhiskeytaster

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Brad Halling on September 12, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.

node.text:
Pausing to remember

I paused on posts about Somalia as I felt it was really important to remember the horrific events of 9/11 on this 20th year anniversary 🙏🏼

The attacks on the World Trade Center in New York resulted in 2,977 of all the deaths. Most were people who were either working or visiting the World Trade Center on that September morning. Also among the lost that day were 343 firefighters and 60 police officers. 

I was blessed to have been invited to share this anniversary and memorial services with several of the men from the different NYFD firehouses. Each of houses memorialized their men their way. I met men that were there that day. I met men that became firefighters after losing their father or brother on 9/11, and I met families who lost fathers or sons. I shared in a service at Rescue 2, a house that had lost all that were on duty that day. I truly empathized with these courageous men. I know what it is like to lose many so quickly. I was thankful to break bread and remember theirs at a firehouse Mass.

If you have never visited a fire house I encourage you to do so. The men that dwell inside those walls are a special breed of men, they truly are courageous, they are brothers, they are a team with bonds as strong as any family, and they are servants to you and I.

I saw many parallels to us who have served and it made it easy to engage as well as feel their loss. While I will remember all that perished that day, I want to say a special thanks to the NYFD for having us as guests and for their unwavering commitment to go into harms way for the lives of others! I was so proud to stand amongst them!

2nd pic are two great Americans that served in the Ranger Regiment before volunteering again as firefighters … what an honor to meet them!

God bless #neverforget #neverforget911 #20thanniversary911 # #fdny #nyfd #bravest #remember #remember911 #moorecounty #moorecountync #ftbraggnc #sanfordnc #fayettevillenc #southernpinesnc #familiesof911 
#1stresponders #antiterrorism #antiterrorist #brothers #grateful #gratitude #worldstopwhiskeytaster @hallingwhiskey

node.text:
Black Hawk Down: Thoughts from my memoirs:  9 Sep 1993

With two operations under our belts, Task Force Ranger was starting to feel a groove. The Russian compound we hit two nights ago, while missing our primary target Mohammed Farrah Aidid, we did capture 2 of Aidid’s Colonels and 11 militia.  It was our hope that we could quickly gather new intelligence to locate and capture Aidid. While happy to have the mission, none of us hoped to be in Mogadishu for Christmas.

One of our techniques to protect the force and it’s mission was to fly signature flights at varying times of the day and night. Today we would fly two flights, one at 1500 with the full force and one at 2020hrs. The second flight we flew with just the Aircrews and snipers. I remember that nights flight being almost peaceful. Even though there was always the possibility of an aircraft strike I felt a calm on these flights, especially when our departure and return would fly us over the ocean. Somehow, in this war torn dusty depleted city, I found beauty at night. The Somalian clans had no night fighting capabilities for the most part so the threat was considered to be low as compared to daytime operations.

Earlier in the day Aidid’s Habr Gidr  clan and another had battled it out on the streets. There were competing clans fighting for control. Control of what I still question today? 

Perhaps their fight had wore them out … our flight was uneventful with the exception of some fires burning in the streets there was little movement in the city ….

node.text:
Black Hawk Down: Thoughts from my memoirs. 
Today, 28 years ago, 07 Sep 0200 hrs in the morning. Task Force Ranger was called to hit a target believed to hold Mohammed Farrah Aidid, the leader of the Somalia National Alliance (SNA) warlord of the Habr Gedir clan. I will never forget looking back at the armada of black hawks and little birds. I was absolutely amazed at the power it projected, the American might! As we came into a flare and the ropes went out, I could feel the adrenaline and anxiety. This would be the beginning of most of the targets we hit during our rotation in Somalia.

Fortunately, the anxiety was short lived and all the training, all the rehearsals quickly turned the anxiety into the likes of just another training event. Soon this target would go down like a day in the shoot house with precision and speed. Proof to me, of the often-spoken words of a prior team sergeant, you will fight as you trained. 

Although I was a sniper, I really preferred getting out of the bird to augment the ground force. I actually had not been a sniper long and felt I was still better suited to work as part of the TF Ranger assault force. Because It was determined due to the size of this target that we should plus up the assault teams I was added to the ground force.  Upon that target, the Russian complex, after sliding down the fast rope I was thankful to be out of the helicopter! I eagerly fell in behind the men I so much respected…

@hallingwhiskey #blackhawkdown #blackhawk #gothicserpent #1911 #car15 #sniper #sniperrifles #moh #purpleheart #taskforceranger #specialoperations #jsoc #usasoc #sealteam6 #ftbragg #ftbraggnc #moorecounty #moorecountync #160thsoar #rltw #dol #southernpines #southernpinesnc #fayettevillenc #sinepari #aberdeennc #sanfordnc #againstallodds #worldstopwhiskeytaster

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Brad Halling on September 03, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, monument, outdoors and text.

node.text:
Stopped by to visit my friends yesterday.  Black Hawk Down: Thoughts from my memoirs.

As we approach another anniversary of the battle of the Black Sea, I hope to share more about the men who fought in that battle. Most of my thoughts come from a journal I wrote during that deployment 28 years ago. 

I have spoken of my good friend Ric Landreth in the past. Ric was an amazing dedicated soldier, teammate, and leader. He had a passion for hunting and was very accomplished as a hunter. The reason for his nickname “Hunter”.

Ric and his team flew on Super 62 through out our deployment with TF Ranger. On the day of the battle Ric was serving as part of Task Force Ranger’s assault force. The last time I was to see Ric that day was as he was reaching for the fast rope disappearing into the brown cloud that had engulfed the men on the rope. Little did Ric or any of the other members of TF Ranger know what kind of a battle they were about to get into! After 18 hours of fighting and a return to the airfield I would see Ric again. Leaning over me like a big brother, Ric reinforced to me that I was going to be alright … an hour later I was on an AirVac on the way to Landstuhl Germany. 

Ric survived the Battle and became an amazing leader, completing 30 years of service. He retired in 2005 at the age of 48 after serving 7 tours in 5 conflicts.

Ric was truly a good man. I am filled with gratitude to have been able to serve with him, hunt with him, and call him a friend. I will forever miss him … he will not be forgotten!

node.text:
Battle of Mogadishu 

Statue of Medal of Honor recipient Master Sergeant Gary Gordon unveiled in his hometown of Lincoln Maine today!

While unable to attend this event, I am so happy to see my teammate and friend forever memorialized in his hometown. Gary was an amazing soldier, husband, father, and friend! He will forever be missed but remembered. 
Some have already asked about the rifle, while not completely accurate for the day, we all trained often with the M21 sniper system. During that deployment Randy carried the M21 so we had a semi auto option while Gary and I had McMillan 300’s as back up for bolt action options. Most engagements were actually made with CAR-15’s … which both Gary and I carried that day.
I was blessed to have him as a friend and teammate…. Never to be forgotten! 
I am especially happy for his amazing family to see this day come to fruition as they were the cornerstone of his existence!

#battleofmogadishu #blackhawkdown #medalofhonor #armysniper #sniper #specialoperations #specialops #m4 #sniperrifle #beyoundthecallofduty #1911 #300magnum #mcmillan #specialforces #10thsfg #moorecountync #moorecountync #hero #friend #ftbragg #ftbraggnc #jsoc #usasoc @garand_thumb #m14 #m21 #CAR15

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Brad Halling on August 27, 2021. May be an image of one or more people.

node.text:
Black Hawk Down: Thoughts from my memoirs

28 years ago this week, I as part of Task Force Ranger, deployed to Somalia to hunt down Mohamed Farrah Aideed. TF Ranger was brought in after Mohamed Aideed and his Somalia National Alliance (SNA) forces, on 5 June 1993, ambushed and killed 24 Pakistani soldiers assigned to UNOSOM II. 

As I look at the events that have occurred in Afghanistan this week I am saddened. I pray for the families of America’s fallen. Unfortunately I am reminded of an Ideology that we faced so long ago!

I look forward to sharing my thoughts surrounding the amazing men and events that lead up to the the anniversary of the Battle of the Black Sea on 3 October 1993!

@hallingwhiskey #bhawk #blackhawkdown #battleoftheblacksea #specialoperations #nsdq #rltw #nightstalkers #blackhawk #super62 #fortbragg #fortcampbell #fortbenning #75thrangerregiment #160thsoar #usasoc #socom #counterterrorism #militaryhistory #fortbragg #fayettevillenc #dol #southernpinesnc #pinehurst #1911 #m4carbine #whiskey #bourbon

node.text:
National Aviation Day: Today, Aug 19th, is a United States national observation that celebrates the development of aviation.

Proclaimed in 1939 by Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who designated the anniversary of Orville Wright's birthday to be National Aviation Day

It is a day of reflection for me, a day in which I remember taking up flight and my good friend Shannon McKinney who taught me to fly.

After being shot down in Somalia I had developed a physical response to flying (see earlier post). To overcome it I took up flight with the help of Shannon “Mac” Mckinney.

I bought my first plane out of California before I had a license. Pictured is me flying over the Golden Gate Bridge in a Zenith 701 STOL homemade aircraft. We took it apart and shipped it back to NC where Mac bravely flew with me while I learned to fly it. After having it a year I eventually got a private pilots license and became proficient at short field take offs and landings.

After losing Mac to cancer in 2016, I lost my flying buddy and and in time I flew less and less and eventually sold the Aircraft.

I am grateful for the memories and the opportunity to fly. I will forever miss my good friend and remember the bravery he displayed when I was plowing through high grass because I couldn’t work the pedals and brake well …. Laughing after he helped get us back on the runway. 

I now miss that old plane but I miss Mac more …. Thank you brother…

node.text:
A little whiskey history!

Pictured here is my 1935 Chevy sedan. Built after prohibition but the same year that the Stitzel-Weller Distilling Company was founded!

The two companies (W. L. Weller & Sons, and the A. Ph. Stitzel) had continued to operate together during Prohibition, selling spirits under a medicinal license. Following the repeal of prohibition by the passage of the Twenty-first Amendment the Stitzel–Weller Distillery was built by Julian “Pappy” Van Winkle Sr. along with Alex T. Farnsley, and Arthur Phillip Stitzel.

Opened in 1935, it became known as the Old Fitzgerald Distillery, after it’s main brand it sold!

Sold in 1972 to Norton-Simon only to be closed in 1992. Although closed, some products, such as Bulleit and Crown Royal continued to be aged there. In 2014, with an infusion of several millions of dollars the distillery was once again opened

Sipping Bulliet… a favorite for Old Fashioned cocktails

Second picture, talking to Julian VanWinkle lll.

node.text:
Berlin with the highly classified clandestine unit PSSE. See video in bio.

Hostage rescue / counter terrorism was added to the plate of the secretive Special Forces units (Det A and PSSE) as a result of the Iran hostage taking in 1979. The units stood up, and or, operated in support of Eagle Claw, TWA 847, the Achille Lauro cruise ship attack, the La Belle disco bombing and the fatal shooting of Military Liaison Mission (MLM) member Maj. “Nick” Nicholson by a Soviet border guard.

Again, conducting this training was difficult as it had to be safeguarded against foreign intelligence agencies and the general public to protect the men’s cover and primary mission under UW.

There were no shoot houses so we filled tires with sand and constructed our shoot houses. Additionally, we tested a lot of European doors and wall materials to make sure we could adequately breach the materials without to much over pressure so as to not harm the hostages.

Why a hole in the door? Some of the European doors were steel and built with multiple dead bolts so attacking a single point such as bolt at door knob or hinges alone could mean failure. @hallingwhiskey #hallingwhiskey #specialforces #hostagerescue #counterterrorism #counterterrorist #clandestine #unconventional #unconventionalwarfare #counterintelligence #berlin #eastberlin #berlinwall #occupationofberlin #alliedforces #nato #hk #hkmp5k #mp5 #ftbragg #ftbraggnc #moorecountync #fayettevillenc #southernpinesnc #sanfordnc #charlottenc #raleigh #pinehurstnc #worldstopwhiskeytaster #socom #jsoc

node.text:
Berlin with the highly classified clandestine unit PSSE. See video in bio.

After the Potsdam conference, July 17 - August 2, 1945, Germany was divided into four occupied zones: Great Britain in the northwest, France in the southwest, the United States in the south and the Soviet Union in the east. Berlin, the capital city situated in Soviet territory, was also divided into four occupied zones. 

Unclear whether it was by design or mere circumstance, but the American sector would contain the shooting ranges built and used by Hitler for the 1936 Olympics. 

With some maintenance and improvements DET A and PSSE would turn these into enclosed ranges that could by used for both marksmanship and CQB out of site of the West Berliners and anyone else’s observations. A critical consideration for a unit that also had a stay behind clandestine mission!  @hallingwhiskey #hallingwhiskey #clandestine #clandestino #coldwar #coldwarhistory #coldwarclips #specialoperations #specialoperationsforces #specialforces #specialforcesgroup #moorecountync #southernpinesnc #aberdeen #mp5 #nightvision #counterterrorism #counterterrorist #sovietoccupation #eastgermany #eastberlin #ftbraggnc #ftbragg #americanforces #blackhawkdown #gothicserpent #worldstopwhiskeytaster

node.text:
Berlin with the highly classified clandestine unit PSSE. See video in bio.

Serving as an Engineer on a Special Forces Operational Detachment, one of the many responsibilities is assessing targets and demolition requirements as well as training the team in charge construction and placement. 

In Berlin, due to the stay behind nature of the mission, we may or may not have had access to resupply of American military explosives. The intent was that the special forces teams already working under cover, would not evacuate the city when the Soviet forces rolled through, but instead stay in place and conduct sabotage operations behind the enemy lines once they passed. This would reduce the risk of trying to infil teams once the conflict started. It also meant that we had to train with European explosive materials and improvised explosives, in the event we couldn’t get resupplied.

Pictured here is me with an improvised pipe bomb.

To this day, I feel thankful and blessed to have served with the men in this unique unit!
